content: A Retrospective of House Rules Changes Since the 110th Congress focuses on rules changes adopted by the House at the beginning of a new Congress, with the majority party organizing the House and making changes to the chamber's rules. The report is part of a series that examines rules changes in the House over multiple Congresses. The report examines rules changes in the House over multiple Congresses, focusing on changes made by the majority party at the beginning of each new Congress. It categorizes the changes into five broad areas and covers the Democratic critique of Republican management during previous Congresses. The report then discusses the Democratic critique of Republican management in the 110th and 111th Congresses, as well as Republican critiques of Democratic management in subsequent Congresses. The report analyzes changes in House rules from the 110th to the 115th Congresses, categorizing them into five broad subject areas. It examines Democratic critiques of Republican and vice versa, as well as policy differences presented during rules debates. The report also looks at how each party drew on its critique when drafting House rules. The report examines changes in House rules from the 110th to the 115th Congresses, categorizing them into five subject areas. It analyzes how each party utilized their critiques when drafting House rules, focusing on rules affecting committees, the Chamber and Floor, budgetary legislation, House administration, and ethics standards. The report catalogs and explains changes to House rules affecting committees or the House floor in the 110th through the 115th Congresses. It supplements the official House Rules and Manual, providing details on rule changes and decisions made by presiding officers. The report does not cover all actions taken during each Congress that impacted organizational structure.
